docs.lead_paragraph: ''When the going gets tough, the tough get going.'' That bit of pep talk has been attributed to both Joseph P. Kennedy and Knute Rockne. Regardless of which of these successful men said it first, there is little doubt that hard times lead to hard decisions, and right now more than a few people have been figuring out ways to trim their personal budgets. ''The world I live in is all about being hip and keeping up with the trends,'' writes Cornelia Frame of Los Angeles, who works in Hollywood as an account executive in an entertainment marketing department.

headline.main: Goodbye Power Lunch. Hello Brown Bag.

docs.abstract: Readers share their ideas for trimming personal budgets; cartoons (M)
docs.snippet: ''When the going gets tough, the tough get going.'' That bit of pep talk has been attributed to both Joseph P. Kennedy and Knute Rockne. Regardless of which of these successful men said it first, there is little doubt that hard times lead to hard...

docs.lead_paragraph: LISTENING to senators and representatives argue about the budget this month, one might have thought that the future of the United States economy was hanging in the balance. After reminding his colleagues that he had taught economics in high school for 16 years, J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, asserted that the budget, including most of the large tax cuts that President Bush had proposed, ''lays down the blueprint for the future of the country.''

headline.main: Both Sides May Be Wrong About The Budget

docs.abstract: David E Rosenbaum column says budget plan adopted by Congress will neither generate all economic growth promised by Republicans nor do grievous harm seen by Democrats (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON and Suffolk County leaders, already fuming over the County Health Department's staff shortages and curtailed services, are demanding an investigation to see if an East Hampton man's death from a heart attack could have been averted if a county clinic had not turned him away just three days before he was stricken. Brian X. Foley, the chairman of the County Legislature's health committee, said the death of 56-year-old Richard M. Flynn ''appears to be the most recent consequence of the breakdown in the county health-care system.'' Mr. Foley, a Democrat from Blue Point, said he asked the Health Department to look into how the county's satellite health clinic in East Hampton had handled Mr. Flynn's case.

headline.main: Suffolk Patient's Death Leads to a Probe

docs.abstract: East Hampton and Suffolk County leaders demand probe to determine whether death of 56-year-old Richard Flynn from heart attack could have been averted if he had not been turned away from county satellite health clinic just three days before he died; friends and fellow health-care advocates say that clinic's services have waned in recent months, other patients have been turned away from appointments or made to wait months and that clinic's only physician is pediatrician who is there two days a week; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the 1980's, the average pay of workers at all income levels is falling. The pay of the nation's top earners has become the most recent to fall behind inflation. The weekly salary of workers at the 90th percentile of earners -- who earn more than nine-tenths of all workers -- fell 1.4 percent over the last year, to $1,439, according to an analysis of government data by the Economic Policy Institute, a research group in Washington.

headline.main: As Companies Reduce Costs, Pay Is Falling Top to Bottom

docs.abstract: Analysis of government data by Economic Policy Institute shows average pay of workers at all income levels is falling for first time since 1980's; finds weekly salary of workers at 90th percentile of earners fell 1.4 percent over last year, to $1,439; Labor Department says inflation-adjusted weekly pay of median worker fell 1.5 percent from early last year to early this year; many companies are turning to pay of employees as they try to stay profitable during economic downturn after more than two years of canceling investments in new equipment and laying off workers; some companies that have frozen or cut wages noted; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For the first time since the 1980's, the average pay of workers at all income levels is falling.    The pay of the nation's top earners has become the most recent to fall behind inflation. The weekly salary of workers at the 90th percentile of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks slipped yesterday as lackluster forecasts from companies like the health insurer Aflac damped the mood on Wall Street after optimism about earnings inspired a hefty two-day rally. Sentiment has improved in recent sessions as many companies matched or surpassed earnings expectations for the first quarter. But after three years of sharp market declines, investors remain wary about prospects for the economy and corporate profits.

headline.main: Shares Slump as Some Companies Issue Weak Forecasts

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 75.62 points, or 0.89 percent, to 8,440.04; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 7.59 points, or 0.83 percent, to 911.43; Nasdaq composite index drops 8.93 points, or 0.61 percent, to 1,457.23; US bonds rise; price of 10-year note rises 14/32, to 99 19/32; yield drops to 3.93 percent from 3.98 percent; 30-year bond gains 23/32, to 108 6/32; yield falls to 4.84 percent from 4.88 percent; graphs; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressman Richard Gephardt's new proposal -- to scrap the 2001 tax cut and use the reclaimed revenue to provide health benefits to the uninsured -- has been widely dismissed as unrealistic. And in political terms that's probably true. After all, these days it's considered ''moderate'' to support an irresponsible tax cut that is merely large, as opposed to gigantic. But today I'd like to take a holiday from political realism, and ask a naïve question: Why shouldn't the American people favor a proposal like Mr. Gephardt's? Never mind the details; why shouldn't the typical citizen, faced with a choice between Bush-style tax cuts and a plan to provide health insurance to most of the uninsured, choose the latter?
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column on Repr Richard Gephardt's proposal to scrap Pres Bush's 2001 tax cut and use reclaimed revenue to provide health benefits to the uninsured; says that if Americans knew what was good for them, most, all but small affluent minority, would cheerfully give up their relatively small share of tax cuts for guarantee that health care would be there when needed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Democratic candidate for president, called yesterday for repealing President Bush's tax cut and using the money to finance a multibillion dollar program to provide health insurance for nearly every American. Mr. Gephardt said his health care plan would effectively require every business to provide subsidized health care insurance for its employees and provide them with federal tax credits equivalent to the cost of 60 percent of the premiums to defray the costs.

headline.main: Gephardt Issues Proposal on Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Rep Richard A Gephardt, Democratic candidate for president, calls for repealing Pres Bush's tax cut and using money to finance program to provide health insurance for nearly every American; says plan would effectively require every business to provide subsidized health care insurance for its employees and provide them with federal tax credits equivalent to cost of 60 percent of premiums to defray costs; puts cost at $692 billion over first three years; is not alone among Democrats in endorsing universal health care, but some rivals are startled by ambition and expense of his proposal, as well as his call for eliminating Bush tax cut to pay for it; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Democratic candidate for president, called yesterday for repealing President Bush's tax cut and using the money to finance a multibillion dollar program to provide health insurance for nearly every American.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators for building owners and apartment building workers said yesterday that both sides had emerged victorious by reaching a settlement at the brink of a strike, but union officials sounded happier than management about the agreement. The tentative three-year contract, announced at 1:10 a.m. yesterday, 70 minutes after a strike deadline, provides raises averaging 2.8 percent a year and increases employer contributions for health coverage and pensions.

headline.main: Both Sides Seen as Winners in Settlement That Averted a Strike by Apartment Workers

docs.abstract: Both sides claim victory as owners and apartment building workers in New York City reach settlement at brink of strike, agreeing to tentative three-year contract; settlement includes wages increases and greater contributions to health coverage and pensions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over providing health care for the 41 million Americans without insurance moved into the realm of dollars and cents yesterday as sponsors of several plans for universal insurance coverage produced cost estimates for the first time. One insurer proposed a plan that would cost $10.2 billion annually to cover 6.6 million people without insurance in California, while a foundation proposed spending $90 billion a year to cover almost every uninsured American.

headline.main: Proposals Attach a Price To Universal Health Care

docs.abstract: Sponsors of several plans to provide health care for 41 million Americans without insurance produce their first cost estimates; Blue Shield of California says its plan to cover 6.6 million uninsured Californians would cost $10.2 billion a year; Commonwealth Fund proposes spending $90 billion a year to cover almost every uninsured American; money to pay for both plans would come from Bush administration tax cuts that have not yet been carried out; employer groups greet proposals warily (M)
